content:
The tracker item about the erroneously introduced trailing slashes of some of our CodeSystem URIs in the FHIR spec: https://www.hl7.org/fhir/terminologies-systems.html was just voted on in the Vocab WG.
Resolution that was voted on:

Approve making this change subject to CGWG making sure that this change doesn't impact any existing implementers, and report this to the Vocab co-chairs to their satisfaction by Friday 27 Sep.

This is the list of the affected codesystems:

  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/refseq/
  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/clinvar/
  • http://varnomen.hgvs.org/

Our job now is to reach out to the genomic community & document the process of doing this.
I'd like to collect the ways of contacting implementers of our IG and do the planning here.
Ways of contact:

  • Post the issue on Zulip (implementers, genomics and terminology)
  • Contact all (possible) implementers via eMail (Members of the WG, search through the attendance documentation of our calls and WGM
  • I have to clarify, but if i understood correctly @Grahame Grieve was willing to have a blog post on his blog about this issue
  • Collect potential implementer contacts known to the WG members which haven't directly participated in calls or meetings
  • create a protected spreadsheet with the contacts and ask Grahame about his opinion if we missed someone, and/or if he has a contact to a identified company for which we don't have a contact person
just checked mCode, the don't use any of the affected URIs
:slight_smile:
I put a message on the announcement channel. @Patrick Werner you should send a variant of this to the FHIR mailing list ASAP. I'll put it in my meeting summary report on Friday
Thanks a lot @Grahame Grieve , will discuss with the rest of the co-chairs today and will get things done ASAP
@Bob Freimuth @Gil Alterovitz @ Bob Milius @Kevin Power

Here is the preview on R4 TC: https://www.hl7.org/fhir/R4B/terminologies-systems.html
The removal of the trailing slashes made it into the TC. The wrong Observation Examples unfortunately not.
